posts.title: Be carefull with precision issue in Numpy
posts.text: The complex type in Numpy According to the official document of Numpy, numpy.complex128 is composed of 2 64-bit-precision floating-point numbers. So, the numpy.complex64 is composed of 2 32-bit-precision floating-point numbers, which might lead to a loss of precision when you assign a numpy.float64 to a numpy.ndarray whose dtype is numpy.complex64. An example At first, we generate two matrices whose type of elements are numpy.complex64 and numpy.float64, 12345678910>>> import numpy as np>>> A = np.zeros((3, 3), dtype = np.complex64)>>> A.dtypedtype('complex64')>>> B = np.random.randn(2, 2)>>> B.dtypedtype('float64')>>> Barray([[-1.39295264, -1.93480849], [-0.18605461, -0.2380665 ]]) now we try to assign the elements of B to A, 1234567>>> A[0:2, 0:2] = B>>> A.dtypedtype('complex64')>>> Aarray([[-1.3929527+0.j, -1.9348085+0.j, 0. +0.j], [-0.1860546+0.j, -0.2380665+0.j, 0. +0.j], [ 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j]], dtype=complex64) we can see that the dtype of A is still complex64, and now we calculate the singular values of A by scipy.linalg.svdvals, 123456>>> from scipy.linalg import svdvals>>> siv = svdvals(A)>>> siv.dtypedtype('float32')>>> sivarray([2.4031136 , 0.01180331, 0. ], dtype=float32) As a result, the dtype of singular values is numpy.float32. Solution We should always fix the number of complex as the two times of float. 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425>>> A = np.zeros((3,3), dtype= np.complex128)>>> B = np.random.randn(2, 2)>>> Aarray([[0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j], [0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j], [0.+0.j, 0.+0.j, 0.+0.j]])>>> A.dtypedtype('complex128')>>> Barray([[-0.0713599 , 1.52210386], [-0.74102553, -0.6968513 ]])>>> B.dtypedtype('float64')>>> A[0:2, 0:2] = B>>> Aarray([[-0.0713599 +0.j, 1.52210386+0.j, 0. +0.j], [-0.74102553+0.j, -0.6968513 +0.j, 0. +0.j], [ 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j, 0. +0.j]])>>> A.dtypedtype('complex128')>>> siv = svdvals(A)>>> siv.dtypedtype('float64')>>> sivarray([1.69531001, 0.6946488 , 0. ])
